blocks.value: St. Gonsalo Garcia was born in Bassein, India, to a Portuguese father and an Indian mother of Brahmin descent. He was raised in the Catholic faith and entered religious life as a Franciscan brother.

Gonsalo Garcia traveled to Japan as a missionary, serving with dedication and courage during a time of intense persecution of Christians. He assisted priests in their ministry and worked to spread the Gospel despite the dangers.

In 1597, during a severe persecution ordered by the ruler Toyotomi Hideyoshi, Gonsalo Garcia was arrested along with 25 other Catholics, including priests and laypeople. They were marched hundreds of miles from Kyoto to Nagasaki. On February 5, 1597, all 26 martyrs were crucified and pierced with spears on a hill in Nagasaki. St. Gonsalo Garcia was canonized by Pope Pius IX in 1862. He is honored as one of the Twenty-Six Martyrs of Japan.
